questions.prompt: The time complexity of a TM is:
options: The maximum steps on any input of length n
questions.explanation: Time complexity f(n) = max steps M uses on any input of length n. We measure worst-case running time.
P = ∪_k TIME(n^k) - languages decidable by a deterministic TM in polynomial time O(n^k) for some k.
Sorting is O(n log n), polynomial time. SAT, TSP optimization, and Hamiltonian path have no known polynomial algorithms.

questions.prompt: P is often considered the class of:
questions.explanation: P represents problems with efficient (polynomial-time) algorithms - the "tractable" problems in complexity theory.

questions.prompt: Why do we use O-notation for time complexity?
options: Exact step counts depend on encoding/model details
questions.explanation: O-notation abstracts away constant factors and lower-order terms that depend on machine model and encoding choices.

title: Class NP and P vs NP

questions.explanation: NP = Nondeterministic Polynomial time - languages accepted by a nondeterministic TM in polynomial time.

questions.prompt: An equivalent definition of NP uses:
questions.explanation: L ∈ NP iff there exists a polynomial-time verifier V and polynomial p such that w ∈ L ⟺ ∃c, |c| ≤ p(|w|), V(w,c) accepts.

options: Every efficiently verifiable problem would be efficiently solvable
questions.explanation: P = NP means problems with easy-to-verify solutions also have easy-to-find solutions. Many "hard" problems become tractable.
Despite lack of proof, decades of failed attempts to find polynomial algorithms for NP-complete problems suggests P ≠ NP.

questions.prompt: The relationship P ⊆ NP holds because:
options: Every NP problem is also in P
A polynomial-time algorithm is also a polynomial-time verifier
NP problems are a subset of P problems
It has been proven that P = NP
questions.explanation: If L ∈ P, we can verify membership by just deciding it (ignoring any certificate). So P ⊆ NP.

options: It is in NP and NP-hard
questions.explanation: NP-complete = in NP (has polynomial verifier) AND NP-hard (all NP problems reduce to it in polynomial time).

questions.prompt: The first problem proven NP-complete was:
questions.explanation: Cook (1971) and Levin proved SAT is NP-complete, establishing the first NP-complete problem and enabling reductions.

questions.prompt: To prove problem B is NP-complete:
options: Show B ∈ NP and reduce a known NP-complete problem to B
questions.explanation: Prove B ∈ NP (give verifier), then reduce a known NP-complete problem A to B (A ≤_p B). This shows B is NP-hard.

questions.prompt: PSPACE is the class of problems solvable in:
questions.explanation: PSPACE = ∪_k SPACE(n^k) - languages decidable using polynomial space, regardless of time.
Savitch's theorem: nondeterministic space can be simulated deterministically with only a square blowup. Thus NPSPACE = PSPACE.
